api/milk.Core.html.title: Namespace milk.Core | milk
api/milk.Core.html.summary: Namespace milk.Core Classes Camera A camera can be added to a Scene via scene.AddCamera(), and draws a scene's world to the screen. Component A component stores data for systems to use, and has some useful additional callback methods. EasingFunctions Describes a set of easing functions to describe (SceneRenderable) movement or (scene) transitions. EngineGlobals EngineResourceManager Entity An Entity is a logical container for components. Systems in a Scene act on entities with the required set of components. EntitySortMethods Methods to control the draw order of entities in a scene. Game A game is the top-level class, and is a subclass of the MonoGame Game class. Image An image can be displayed within a scene. InputManager Used to receive and respond to player input. Scene A scene is a collection of entities and systems, and can be thought of as game 'screens'. Each system in a scene acts on all entities in the scene with the required set of components. SceneRenderable Used as a superclass for images, text, UI, etc. Sprite A sprite is added to a SpriteComponent, and is a collection of textures, along with some additional data. A sprite with more than one texture automatically becomes an animated sprite. System A system within a scene runs on entities with the reqiured set of components. Text Displays text in a scene, in the font specified. Theme Transition Utilities Utils Enums Anchor The part of a SceneRenderable to set the position against. Delegates EasingFunctions.EasingDelegate Represents a delegate for an easing function. An easing function takes a single float parameter (typically a normalized time value from 0 to 1) and returns a float value, which is the eased output.

api/milk.html.title: Namespace milk | milk
api/milk.html.summary: Namespace milk Classes Camera ColliderComponent Component A component stores data for systems to use, and has some useful additional callback methods. EasingFunctions EngineGlobals Entity An Entity is a logical container for components. Systems in a Scene act on entities with the required set of components. EntitySortMethods Game Image InputComponent InputManager InputSystem LightingComponent LightingSystem PhysicsComponent PhysicsSystem Scene A scene is a collection of entities and systems, and can be thought of as game 'screens'. Each system in a scene acts on all entities in the scene with the required set of components. SceneRenderable Sprite SpriteComponent SpriteSystem System A system within a scene runs on entities with the reqiured set of components. Text Theme TransformComponent Transition TriggerComponent TriggerEntity TriggerSystem Utilities Utils Enums Anchor Delegates EasingFunctions.EasingDelegate Represents a delegate for an easing function. An easing function takes a single float parameter (typically a normalized time value from 0 to 1) and returns a float value, which is the eased output.

docs/getting-started.html.title: Getting Started | milk
docs/getting-started.html.summary: Getting Started Simplest use The code below is the simplest code that will create a new game. It will just show the default, placeholder scene, but is useful for testing that everything is installed and working: using milk.Core; using var game = new Game(); game.Run(); Basic usage To create a basic single-scene game, firstly create a new scene subclass: using Microsoft.Xna.Framework; using milk.Core; public class MyScene : Scene { public override void Init() { BackgroundColor = Color.CornflowerBlue; } } You can then create a new game with this class using the following code: using milk.Core; using var game = new Game(); game.Init = () => { game.SetScene(new MyScene()); }; game.Run(); 'Tiny Town' Example See the Tiny Town GitHub repo for an in-development RPG made with milk.

docs/introduction.html.title: Introduction | milk
docs/introduction.html.summary: Introduction MonoGameECS is a minimal, beginner-friendly engine that prioritises ease of use. This means that the long-term goals for the project are: Minimal setup, e.g. users do not need to register components. Interaction only with tangible objects, e.g. entity.AddComponent(component) rather than componentManager.AddComponentToEntity(entity, component). Maximise default object values, e.g. myImage = new Image() should be possible (creating a 'blank' placeholder image). Clear, fully commented code. This repo should serve as a guide to simple ECS development.
